image.altText: Two men, one of them shirtless, smile with their arms around each other at an indoor pool.

props.synopsis: For the past seven years, Peter Thorn has thrived under his National Disability Insurance Scheme plan — until earlier this year, when he was told there had been an "error" and his seven days of overnight support per week were cut to just seven days a year.

title.children: Peter's NDIS funding was cut suddenly after years of support, affecting many areas of his life

image.altText: A bald man in a black suit and white button down shirt without a tie looks serious.

props.synopsis: Newly-elected MLA Thomas Emerson caused some furore when he turned up to day one of the ACT's Legislative Assembly sans-tie, with the speaker warning of a "dramatic decline" of dress standards. But is it time to get with the times, and ditch the tie altogether?

title.children: A politician's refusal to wear a tie has prompted the question of their relevance

image.altText: A public bus with a wrap on the back that reads "MyWay+".

props.synopsis: Speaking to Stateline, ACT Chief Minister Andrew Barr concedes the government should have waited several more days before rolling out a new public transport ticketing system that was plagued with problems as it went live.

title.children: ACT government concedes it should have postponed MyWay+ rollout

image.altText: A young girl gives the thumbs up while wearing a Parramatta Eels jersey.

props.synopsis: Rozalia Spadafora's mother was holding back tears but she did not mince her words when she spoke about Canberra Health Services following the coronial inquest into her daughter's untimely death.

title.children: What this five-year-old's death tells us about the state of the ACT health system

image.altText: Canberra Hospital taxi near emergency department

props.synopsis: New data shows the average time patients spent being treated in ACT emergency departments has improved in the past financial year, but Canberra Health Services still failed to meet all but one of its emergency wait-time targets.

title.children: Canberra has shortest emergency department stay in the country, but fails on other fronts

image.altText: A laptop computer sits open on a bed in a dark room showing an email account on screen.

props.synopsis: The Canberra woman, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was prepared to pay $20,000 for her parents to be killed and had paid $7,500 towards that goal.

title.children: Woman spared further jail time after hiring hit man to kill parents on dark web

image.altText: A building sign that reads 'ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal'.

props.synopsis: The ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal found the ACT government discriminated against the public servant over her criminal history.

title.children: ACT government ordered to pay former employee $265k after finding she was discriminated against

image.altText: Elderly man in striped shirt sitting in front of the King's Carriage

props.synopsis: Jim Frecklington, best known as the world's last royal coachmaker, has almost finished a 3-tonne gold-leaf embossed carriage for King Charles III despite undergoing treatment for cancer.

title.children: Craftsman with 'one of the rarest skills' nearly finished ride fit for king

image.altText: A man's hand drops a bottle containing a sperm into a woman's hand.

props.synopsis: Those powering Facebook's sperm exchange say they want options and they want control. But in this unregulated space, it's not always clear who's in control and who isn't.

title.children: Craig used Facebook to make a baby with strangers, then came torment

image.altText: Man putting food waste into a stainless steel drum

props.synopsis: Australia means so much to Iranian-born biotechnologist Sam Jahangard, he has made a huge sacrifice to keep his developments in the country instead of selling them internationally.

title.children: Scientist turns down $500 million to keep waste-to-compost invention in Australia

image.altText: A map of Australia.

props.synopsis: As climate change progresses, the CSIRO has created the first detailed national maps to help Australians understand the future risk to their properties.

title.children: These maps reveal Australia's potential bushfire future for every postcode

image.altText: A long exposure shows a nuclear plant illuminated at night, with a white cloud of steam emerging from the top of two reactors.

props.synopsis: Amid a fierce political debate over energy policy, the Labor-led nuclear inquiry was seen as a tactic to discredit the Coalition's policy and stir up opposition in the regional communities where it wants to build reactors. But after weeks of public hearings, the Opposition is making the most of the opportunity to spruik its plans.

title.children: Labor's nuclear inquiry either a 'political stitch-up' or 'own goal'

image.altText: Children hold protest signs

props.synopsis: In New Zealand, the prime minister has ruled out a referendum on the Treaty of Waitangi, but legal experts warn there are multiple paths to a nationwide vote.

title.children: Quirk of NZ democracy could play key role in treaty debate

image.altText: The Notre Dame at dusk, with a projection on the side lighting it up in neon green, pink and light blue.

props.synopsis: The 860-year-old cathedral has been meticulously restored and reopened with a red carpet ceremony to the sound of the landmark's historic bells.

title.children: Notre Dame reopens with star-studded ceremony

image.altText: Spirit of Tasmania IV ship in port.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's government has paid for double-page ads across three newspapers to address "frequently asked questions" about why the Spirit of Tasmania ferries are still a long way off operating — with Labor saying the ads are a "blatant waste" of money.

title.children: 'Blatant waste': Critics lash double-page ads explaining ferry debacle

image.altText: A small white car surrounded by police tape.

props.synopsis: Two have been hospitalised with serious stab wounds after being attacked by a group of men in Melbourne's outer north-west on Saturday night.

title.children: Police investigate Melbourne stabbing spree

image.altText: Pedestrian walks past Reserve Bank building in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of Australia hasn't changed the crash rate target for more than a year. Some economists reckon we won't see a cut for at least another few months.

title.children: Three of Big Four banks reckon rate cuts won't happen until autumn

image.altText: A man stands in a backyard with his arms crossed, looking into camera with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Gambling reform advocates say greater action is needed to crack down on offshore gambling operators who are illegally targeting Australians, including recovered addicts.

title.children: Gambling companies accused of using 'loser lists' to target addicts

image.altText: Elderly man in striped shirt sitting in front of the King's Carriage

props.synopsis: Jim Frecklington, best known as the world's last royal coachmaker, has almost finished a 3-tonne gold-leaf embossed carriage for King Charles III despite undergoing treatment for cancer.

title.children: Craftsman with 'one of the rarest skills' nearly finished ride fit for king

image.altText: Tiesha

props.synopsis: A survey finds more than half of people aged 18 to 29 with a credit card sign up solely to earn travel rewards points, but 60 per cent are struggling to clear their debts each month.

title.children: Discounted flights come at cost as young people fail to pay travel reward credit cards

image.altText: A cardinal wearing cardinal robes standing next to a statue inside an old building in the Vatican.

props.synopsis: The Ukrainian-born missionary says he aims to be a cardinal who is "flexible, holy, accessible and without eminence".

title.children: Australian-based Ukrainian bishop now world's youngest cardinal at 44

image.altText: Beach at the Gold Coast with swimmer and surfers in the water.

props.synopsis: The wife of a paddleboarder seriously injured by a boat propeller at Currumbin Alley wants more signage warning of potential danger at popular surf breaks.

title.children: Fears of more boardrider versus boat collisions as Gold Coast crowds swell

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: Call yourself a trivia master? Show us what you've got.

title.children: Think you're a big cheese when it comes to trivia? Prove it!

image.altText: Portrait of three men against a dark theatre background.

props.synopsis: Jay Laga'aia is proud of his children, five of whom have followed him into show business. It's something he initially didn't want them to do.

title.children: Jay Laga'aia didn't want his kids to become performers

image.altText: An English cyclist leads the way ahead of a rival in a women's sprint event on a velodrome.

props.synopsis: A British Olympic cyclist is taken to hospital but reportedly avoids serious injury after being launched over the barriers into the London Velodrome crowd with a rival during a big track cycling event.

title.children: Olympic champion cyclist Marchant hospitalised after track crash

image.altText: Sketch of school children at a large table. Four gathered at one end with a teacher and one alone at the other under a spotlight

props.synopsis: Raising a child with exceptional academic potential, perhaps destined solve the world's most pressing problems, sounds like a breeze. But even those who are identified as "gifted" can struggle to find the right path through school.

title.children: Gifted and ignored: The smart kids who can't afford to succeed

image.altText: Phonics student writes word

props.synopsis: Primary school children are being taught the building blocks of language via a method that has had proven success overseas.

title.children: Victorian students to sit new test as part of move to 'phonics'

image.altText: A woman wrapped in a green, red, blue and yellow flag of New Caledonia's independence movement.

props.synopsis: The collapse of France's government has thrown New Caledonia into fresh uncertainty as it tries to recover from its worst civil unrest in decades.

title.children: Collapse of France's government risks New Caledonia's fragile recovery

image.altText: An image of Vanessa Alford with her son Otis standing on a veranda with a leafy background

props.synopsis: Vanessa Alford moved across the country so her children could attend a primary school in Brisbane — one of very few that provides a specialist program for deaf and hard-of-hearing students. But what happens when kids go to high school?

title.children: Calls for high school education program for deaf and hard-of-hearing children

image.altText: Travis Head looks up towards the crowd while wearing his baggy green

props.synopsis: As proactive and frenetic as ever, Travis Head enjoyed a day in Adelaide where everything went right and his thrilling knock has set Australia on the path to a critical victory.

title.children: Head knows only full throttle, and it's leading Australia to victory

image.altText: Three men on the verandah of the post disaster proto type at Southern Cross University

props.synopsis: Engineers hope easy-to-erect, sustainable cardboard homes may provide the answer to crisis accommodation after floods and bushfires.

title.children: Sustainable cardboard homes may provide post-disaster accommodation

image.altText: Georgia Voll plays a leg glance off her pads during an ODI in the morning

props.synopsis: Centuries to Georgia Voll and Ellyse Perry have pushed Australia well passed 300 as they set India a massive run chase in Brisbane. Follow live.

title.children: Voll and Perry score centuries as Australia pile on the runs

image.altText: A young boy holds a fishing rod.

props.synopsis: A new generation learns to love Central Queensland's Dawson River and carries on the sense of community that is etched into the fabric of the tiny town of Theodore.

title.children: Tiny town carved a future when its grand irrigation scheme failed

image.altText: finished dish of corned beef and vegetables with a finishing sauce

props.synopsis: This is Alice Zaslavsky's take on a classic corned beef dish.

title.children: Corned beef with mash and mustard sauce

image.altText: profile portrait of Aboriginal woman

props.synopsis: Maureen Deegan's mum had to relearn her own language, Jaru, which she had not been allowed to speak. Now Maureen is helping others to keep their languages alive.

title.children: The fight to reverse the tide of language extinction in the Kimberley
